title: The Comedy of Errors
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Comedy of Errors is one of William Shakespeare's early plays. It is his shortest and one of his most farcical comedies, with a major part of the humour coming from slapstick and mistaken identity, in addition to puns and word play.

title: Believe as You List
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Believe as You List is a play by Philip Massinger, exploring themes of loyalty and identity.

title: Hamlet
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Hamlet is a tragedy written by William Shakespeare sometime between 1599 and 1601. It is Shakespeare's longest play and is among the most powerful and influential tragedies in English literature.

title: Romeo and Juliet
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Romeo and Juliet is a tragedy written early in the career of William Shakespeare about two young star-crossed lovers whose deaths ultimately reconcile their feuding families.

title: Macbeth
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Macbeth is a tragedy by William Shakespeare. It is thought to have been first performed in 1606. It is one of Shakespeare's most famous and popular works.

title: Othello
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Othello is a tragedy by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written in 1603. The play centers on the character Othello, a Moorish general, and his ensign, Iago.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: A Midsummer Night's Dream is a comedy written by William Shakespeare in 1595/96. The play is one of Shakespeare's most popular works for the stage and is widely performed across the world.

title: Julius Caesar
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Julius Caesar is a tragedy by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written in 1599. It is one of several Roman plays that Shakespeare wrote, based on true events from Roman history.

title: The Tempest
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Tempest is a play by William Shakespeare, probably written in 1610–1611. It is considered one of Shakespeare's late romances.

title: King Lear
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: King Lear is a tragedy written by William Shakespeare. It depicts the gradual descent into madness of the title character, after he disposes of his kingdom giving bequests to two of his three daughters based on their flattery of him.

title: Twelfth Night
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Twelfth Night is a comedy by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written around 1601–1602. It centers on the twins Viola and Sebastian, who are separated in a shipwreck.

title: The Merchant of Venice
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Merchant of Venice is a 16th-century play by William Shakespeare in which a merchant in Venice must default on a large loan provided by a Jewish moneylender, Shylock.

title: Much Ado About Nothing
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Much Ado About Nothing is a comedy by William Shakespeare thought to have been written in 1598 and 1599. The play was included in the First Folio, published in 1623.

title: Richard III
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Richard III is a historical play by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written around 1593. It depicts the Machiavellian rise to power and subsequent short reign of King Richard III of England.

title: Antony and Cleopatra
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Antony and Cleopatra is a tragedy by William Shakespeare. It was first performed around 1607 and depicts the relationship between Cleopatra and Mark Antony.

title: Coriolanus
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Coriolanus is a tragedy by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written between 1605 and 1608. The play is based on the life of the legendary Roman leader Caius Marcius Coriolanus.

title: Henry V
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Henry V is a history play by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written near 1599. It focuses on King Henry V of England, and events before and after the Battle of Agincourt during the Hundred Years' War.

title: As You Like It
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: As You Like It is a pastoral comedy by William Shakespeare believed to have been written in 1599 and first published in the First Folio in 1623.

title: Measure for Measure
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Measure for Measure is a play by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written in 1603 or 1604. It is often classified as a comedy, though its themes are more serious and introspective.

title: The Taming of the Shrew
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Taming of the Shrew is a comedy by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written between 1590 and 1592.

title: All's Well That Ends Well
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: All's Well That Ends Well is a play by William Shakespeare, first published in the First Folio in 1623, although it was probably written earlier.

title: Timon of Athens
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Timon of Athens is a play by William Shakespeare, probably written in collaboration with Thomas Middleton, about the fortunes and misfortunes of the title character, a wealthy Athenian.

title: Titus Andronicus
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Titus Andronicus is a tragedy by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written between 1588 and 1593, probably in collaboration with George Peele.

title: Love's Labour's Lost
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Love's Labour's Lost is one of William Shakespeare's early comedies, believed to have been written in the mid-1590s.

title: Pericles, Prince of Tyre
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Pericles, Prince of Tyre is a play written at least in part by William Shakespeare and first performed in 1608.

title: Troilus and Cressida
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Troilus and Cressida is a tragedy by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written in 1602.

title: Cymbeline
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Cymbeline is a play by William Shakespeare, based on legends concerning the early Celtic British King Cunobeline.

title: The Two Gentlemen of Verona
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Two Gentlemen of Verona is a comedy by William Shakespeare, and one of his earliest plays, believed to have been written in the early 1590s.

title: Henry IV, Part 1
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Henry IV, Part 1 is a history play by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written no later than 1597.

title: Henry IV, Part 2
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Henry IV, Part 2 is a history play by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written between 1596 and 1599.

title: Henry VI, Part 1
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Henry VI, Part 1 is a history play by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written in 1591.

title: Henry VI, Part 2
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Henry VI, Part 2 is a history play by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written in 1591.

title: Henry VI, Part 3
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Henry VI, Part 3 is a history play by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written in 1591.

title: Henry VIII
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Henry VIII is a collaborative history play, believed to have been written by William Shakespeare and John Fletcher in 1613.

title: The Winter's Tale
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Winter's Tale is a play by William Shakespeare, originally published in the First Folio of 1623, and it is considered one of Shakespeare's late romances.

title: The Two Noble Kinsmen
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Two Noble Kinsmen is a play co-written by William Shakespeare and John Fletcher, published in 1634.

title: Edward III
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Edward III is a play sometimes attributed to William Shakespeare, though its authorship is disputed.

title: Thomas More
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Thomas More is a play written by several playwrights, including William Shakespeare. It is based on the life of Sir Thomas More.

title: Arden of Faversham
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Arden of Faversham is an Elizabethan play sometimes attributed to William Shakespeare, revolving around the murder of Thomas Arden.

title: Cardenio
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Cardenio is a lost play, attributed to William Shakespeare and John Fletcher, based on an episode in Miguel de Cervantes's Don Quixote.

title: Sir Thomas More
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Sir Thomas More is a play by several writers, including William Shakespeare, portraying the life of Thomas More.

title: Fair Em
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Fair Em is an Elizabethan play of uncertain authorship sometimes attributed to William Shakespeare.

title: Mucedorus
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Mucedorus is an Elizabethan play, sometimes attributed to William Shakespeare, that tells the tale of a shepherd prince and his love.

title: The Birth of Merlin
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Birth of Merlin is a play sometimes attributed to William Shakespeare and William Rowley.

title: The Merry Devil of Edmonton
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Merry Devil of Edmonton is an anonymous Elizabethan comedy that has been occasionally attributed to William Shakespeare.

title: The Arraignment of Paris
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Arraignment of Paris is a play by George Peele, though once attributed to William Shakespeare.

title: Locrine
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Locrine is a play that was once attributed to William Shakespeare, though its authorship is disputed.

title: The London Prodigal
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The London Prodigal is a play included in the Shakespeare Apocrypha, attributed to Shakespeare, but authorship is uncertain.

title: A Yorkshire Tragedy
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: A Yorkshire Tragedy is a play included in the Shakespeare Apocrypha and was attributed to Shakespeare in 1608.

title: The Puritan
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Puritan is a comedy sometimes attributed to William Shakespeare, though authorship is disputed.

title: A Knack to Know a Knave
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: A Knack to Know a Knave is an Elizabethan play sometimes included in the Shakespeare Apocrypha.

title: The Troublesome Reign of King John
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Troublesome Reign of King John is an anonymous Elizabethan play occasionally attributed to William Shakespeare.

title: The Tragedy of Caesar and Pompey
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Tragedy of Caesar and Pompey is a play occasionally attributed to Shakespeare but likely not his work.

title: The Taming of A Shrew
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Taming of A Shrew is an anonymous play that parallels Shakespeare's The Taming of the Shrew.

title: Edward IV
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Edward IV is a play sometimes associated with Shakespeare's era, though its authorship is uncertain.

title: Sir John Oldcastle
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Sir John Oldcastle is a play sometimes attributed to William Shakespeare.

title: The Famous Victories of Henry V
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Famous Victories of Henry V is an anonymous play that portrays events later covered in Shakespeare's Henry IV and Henry V plays.

title: The Second Maiden's Tragedy
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Second Maiden's Tragedy is a Jacobean play sometimes associated with Shakespeare.

title: Philaster
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Philaster is a play by Beaumont and Fletcher, sometimes associated with Shakespearean style.

title: The Revenger's Tragedy
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Revenger's Tragedy is a Jacobean play, sometimes attributed to Thomas Middleton but originally considered as possibly Shakespeare's work.

title: The Spanish Tragedy
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Spanish Tragedy is an influential play by Thomas Kyd, sometimes linked to Shakespeare's work due to thematic similarities.

title: The Maid's Tragedy
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Maid's Tragedy is a play by Beaumont and Fletcher, showcasing themes of betrayal and revenge that echo Shakespearean elements.

title: The Changeling
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Changeling is a tragedy by Thomas Middleton and William Rowley, often compared to Shakespeare for its dark themes and psychological depth.

title: The Roaring Girl
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Roaring Girl is a comedy by Thomas Middleton and Thomas Dekker, reflecting themes of gender roles and identity.

title: The Duchess of Malfi
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Duchess of Malfi is a tragedy by John Webster, celebrated for its poetic language and complex themes similar to Shakespearean tragedies.

title: Doctor Faustus
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Doctor Faustus is a tragedy by Christopher Marlowe that explores themes of ambition and the supernatural, drawing comparisons to Shakespeare's work.

title: The Alchemist
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Alchemist is a comedy by Ben Jonson that satirizes greed and gullibility, sharing comedic traits with Shakespeare's works.

title: Volpone
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Volpone is a dark comedy by Ben Jonson, often discussed alongside Shakespearean works for its satirical tone.

title: Bartholomew Fair
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Bartholomew Fair is a comedy by Ben Jonson that explores human nature through humor, similar to Shakespeare’s comedies.

title: The Jew of Malta
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Jew of Malta is a play by Christopher Marlowe, known for its themes of revenge and ambition.

title: Women Beware Women
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Women Beware Women is a tragedy by Thomas Middleton, often compared to Shakespeare for its tragic themes.

title: The Revenger's Tragedy
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Revenger's Tragedy is a dark play by Thomas Middleton, with themes reminiscent of Shakespearean revenge tragedies.

title: A Chaste Maid in Cheapside
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: A Chaste Maid in Cheapside is a satire by Thomas Middleton, noted for its humorous exploration of society similar to Shakespeare's comedies.

title: The Honest Whore
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Honest Whore is a two-part play by Thomas Dekker, exploring themes of morality and redemption.

title: The Knight of the Burning Pestle
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Knight of the Burning Pestle is a satirical play by Francis Beaumont, noted for its humor and unique structure.

title: The Spanish Tragedy
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Spanish Tragedy is a revenge play by Thomas Kyd that influenced Shakespeare's Hamlet.

title: Arden of Faversham
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Arden of Faversham is an Elizabethan play sometimes attributed to Shakespeare, known for its focus on domestic tragedy.

title: Edward II
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Edward II is a historical tragedy by Christopher Marlowe, comparable to Shakespeare's history plays.

title: The Shoemaker's Holiday
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Shoemaker's Holiday is a comedy by Thomas Dekker that offers a glimpse into the lives of common people.

title: Dido, Queen of Carthage
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Dido, Queen of Carthage is a play by Christopher Marlowe that explores themes of love and betrayal.

title: The White Devil
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The White Devil is a tragedy by John Webster, noted for its dark themes and complex characters.

title: The Witch
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Witch is a tragedy by Thomas Middleton, exploring themes of witchcraft and moral corruption.

title: Philaster
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Philaster is a romantic drama by Beaumont and Fletcher, known for its themes of love and identity.

title: The Knight of Malta
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Knight of Malta is a tragicomedy by John Fletcher and Philip Massinger.

title: The Widow's Tears
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Widow's Tears is a dark comedy by George Chapman, known for its exploration of grief and resilience.

title: The Atheist's Tragedy
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Atheist's Tragedy is a play by Cyril Tourneur, exploring themes of morality and vengeance.

title: Cupid's Revenge
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Cupid's Revenge is a tragedy by Beaumont and Fletcher that explores the destructive nature of unrequited love.

title: The Island Princess
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Island Princess is a tragicomedy by John Fletcher that explores themes of loyalty and honor.

title: The Sea Voyage
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Sea Voyage is a tragicomedy by Fletcher and Massinger, known for its adventurous plot and exotic setting.

title: Bonduca
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: Bonduca is a historical tragedy by John Fletcher, focusing on the resistance of a British queen against Rome.

title: The Scornful Lady
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Scornful Lady is a comedy by Beaumont and Fletcher that deals with themes of love and pride.

title: The Faithful Shepherdess
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Faithful Shepherdess is a pastoral tragicomedy by John Fletcher, exploring themes of love and innocence.

title: The Parliament of Love
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Parliament of Love is a comedy by Philip Massinger, exploring themes of love and virtue.

title: The Emperor of the East
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Emperor of the East is a tragicomedy by Philip Massinger that examines themes of power and morality.

title: The Fatal Dowry
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Fatal Dowry is a tragedy by Philip Massinger and Nathan Field, noted for its examination of justice and honor.

title: The Renegado
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Renegado is a tragicomedy by Philip Massinger, exploring themes of faith and redemption.

title: A New Way to Pay Old Debts
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: A New Way to Pay Old Debts is a comedy by Philip Massinger, known for its satire of greed and corruption.

title: The Roman Actor
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Roman Actor is a tragedy by Philip Massinger that explores themes of tyranny and justice.

title: The City Madam
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The City Madam is a comedy by Philip Massinger that criticizes social ambition and greed.

title: The Unnatural Combat
description_html: Wikipedia Summary: The Unnatural Combat is a tragedy by Philip Massinger that delves into themes of betrayal and family conflict.
